tspan.tspan: Global Ad

text.tspan: Profits are publically used for future development?

tspan.tspan: Server-specific ad

text.tspan: One entity owns a cluster of servers (bandwidth pipe(s)), all of which have

tspan.tspan: /b/-esq content stream
Perhaps a realtime timeline (realtimeline?)
I like the idea of auto-scrolling, but also the
idea of "every item must be clicked 'next' on
so that every item can be seen (because with auto-
scrolling, your eyes might not be able to keep up)"
- All content is >= DPL. CLA at registration. Guest/
non-logged-in gets read-only view
- Content is signed by master key, so the entity
owning and profiting from the 'Server-specific ad'
above can not do MITM attack. Content must be
delivered in a 'rolling hash' (like git commits and/or
bitcoin block chain) from the server to the
'client' (front-end. web-view to start (out of
NECESSITY (i h8 http/www/html 'web' tbh)), but
maybe a local binary eventually. the web front-end
would need to have authenticity verifying
javascripts, it cannot be done server side (only)
otherwise the entity controlling the Server-specific
ad can game the system (MITM))
-Longer term: any 'Server-specific ad' should even
be able to run their own ABC impl for the server-
specific ad, so they don't lost the 3% fee either.
-Content is permanent, unlike /b/. Only deleitions:
law breaking content. This is just like /b/ already, but
the fact that content is permanent and that a CLA
must be signed at registration will cater to a
completely different audience and there will be
vastly different (and arguably lower quality) content.
-Registration must be 'accepted'. You voice/video
authenticate by reading out loud your details and an
auto-generated string of random characters. You are
responsible for all your content, and repeat
copyright infringers are b&. Tangent/future-addon:
content must be tagged as 'referring to non-
cleanroom content' when it is, so that those who
wish to block it out ENTIRELY, can. Because
mentioning _IS_ fair use, so belongs IN the clean-
room, BUT it's is certainly understandable that some
people might want to block it out entirely. I am one
of them, however I would have to block out the
system's entire ability to 'refer to' non-cleanroom in
order for myself to simultaneously (a) be intolerant
of non-cleanroom content, and (b) be DMCA
compliant (since I'd HAVE TO do DMCA sweeps on
content in the non cleanroom 'section', if I allow the
content to enter my server [and out again for
distr)ibution]. I am extremely tempted, of course, to
not allow any non-cleanroom 'references' on the
system entirely, but am undecided atm
-Anonymity and authenticity contradict each other,
so the ONLY form of anonymity that is advertised is
weak anonymity among friends who value
anonymity. But of course, it should always be known
that the documents are not truly anonymous so as
not to mislead the writer or reader. Basically as
simple as this: when you post a document, you can
opt into putting "better when considered
anonymously". If the receiver of said document also
values anonymity, they take it upon themselves to
not view the name of the author/contributor of the
doc (an author is MANDATORY btw, since the whole
system is signed/verified). In this way we get
anonymity and authenticity simultaneously. There
are a lot of ways that anonymity system could be
abused, so maybe it is eventually determined better
off to not exist. It is an experiment, because I do
value anonymity.
"Cleanroom"

text.tspan: I can hack together a simple website (detailed below) for the cleanroom concept (all information deriveable), but a
proper impl should live on a resillient P2P DHT
